A&AT LLC Waynesboro
Waynesboro, VA

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)

Introduction and Policies

A&AT LLC is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. A&AT LLC's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Waynesboro facility is operated by A&AT LLC effective January 1, 2018 to produce Lycra(Trademark Registered) and Hyfit(Trademark Registered) brand spandex.  The branded spandex is made in a plant that was put into service in the early 1960s and is referred to as the Classic plant. The Classic facility is located near the center of the plant. It consists of three basic areas: polymer processing, spinning and recovery. The site also has the Benger R&D facility and a Chemistry lab. Both of these facilities have the primary responsibility of support for spandex operations.

The site also has its own Powerhouse and utility support. The Powerhouse has two <99MMBtu boilers, which burn natural gas, but can use small amounts of #2 fuel oil. Three coal boilers were permanently shutdown in 2014.

In the spandex facilities polymer processing uses an aromatic diisocyanate (Diphenylmethane diisocyanate MDI) combined with glycol in a heated reactor to form the base polyurethane polymer, or

capped glycol. A polymer solution called diluted capped glycol is formed by the addition of a solvent N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc). The diluted capped glycol solution is transferred to a second reactor where various reagents are added to determine the properties of the polymer, such as chain length.

Ethylenediamine (1,2-Ethanediamine) is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Waynesboro facility in amounts above threshold quantity. This chemical is used as an additive in the spandex polymer process. The facility is regulated under the Program Level 1 requirements.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by A&AT LLC. These high standards include:

Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

Prevention Program

The Waynesboro facility is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety has helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years. Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

A tank and delivery containment system that will easily accommodate a complete release of Ethylenediamine from both tanks if they we

re at full capacity.
Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
Minimizing the possibility of a release of Ethylenediamine by having emergency shutdown systems at the loading areas.
Reducing the risk of overfilling by having level alarms and/or indicators on storage tanks and bullets.
Implementing procedures for loading/unloading operations that help prevent a truck driver from driving away before the loading arm is properly disconnected.

Five-Year Accident History

Within the last five years, there have been no releases of RMP substances that resulted in onsite injuries, death or property damage or offsite impacts.

Emergency Response Program

The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Waynesboro facility with the Augusta LEPC. As appropriate, also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Virginia State Police, the Waynesboro police and fire department and Augusta Medical Center. The City of Waynesboro Fire Chief has the authority to assume Incident Command (IC) of any emergency scene or incident within the boundaries of the City of Waynesboro. In his absence, the Department on duty shift Commander will serve in his capacity. The A&AT LLC Emergency Services Team Leader shall act as the A&AT LLC Incident Commander. The A&AT LLC Plant Manager or his designate has overall responsibility for Site personnel, buildings, and equipment. A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials. The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework for conti

nuous safety improvement. Some of the key components of the safety program are:

The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Job Safety Analysis (JSA) provisions serve as tools to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:

Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
An ongoing dialogue with the Augusta County LEPC Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Augusta County Local Emergency Planning Commission or the Waynesboro City Fire Department for the latest information on emergency response for the county or city. The facility coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county and city on an ongoing basis.
